title: Getting Started
content: Getting Started Welcome to MTH 121 Survey of Calculus and Its Applications 1

title: Overview
description: A brief overview of the exam format and what you should be doing to study.
content:
How to Study   Start early! Remember, you should be staying on pace with the lecture schedule. It will not be a fun experience if you wait until a day or so before the exam to start your work.
  Review your Online Homework problems. As you complete the homework problems, write down your full solutions with explanations in a neat, organized notebook. This way when exam time comes, you have a nice solutions manual, you created yourself - that you can then refer back to if you get stuck on a problem. Again, get started early! A day or so before the exam should be spent reviewing homework problems, not looking at them for the first time.
  Review your notes. As you watch the lectures, you should be taking detailed notes in a neat, organized notebook. You can then retry any of the examples as additional practice. The possible exam questions that we have listed in the study guides follow the notes pretty closely.
  Review the Additional Practice Textbook problems. These are listed in the Exam Study Guides and are a more focused subset of problems chosen from the already-assigned ungraded textbook problems.
  Review the Ungraded Textbook Homework problems. Being successful on the exams really comes down to practice, practice, practice.
  Start early! Did I mention this already?
  Difficulty The questions you will see on the exams are, on average, slightly easier than the online homework questions. This is by design:
  It is better to be over-prepared than under-prepared. Having more-challenging homework questions better prepares you for the task of answering questions in a timed setting like an exam.
  Some interesting questions are best asked in a homework setting where you have more time to let them fully digest.
  Exam Format Each exam will consist of two parts: a short-answer section and a long-answer section.
Short-Answer Questions These are designed to test basic comprehension and understanding of the material. Each is worth 1 point and will be graded as either correct or incorrect.
 You will only state your answer for these problems. You will not need to show your work. A few of these questions may ask for you to only state a result, definition, or name a theorem. Some of these questions may require minimal work, with calculations that can be done in your head. e.g. Evaluate a function or compute a derivative using the power rule.  Long-Answer Questions These are designed to test a deeper understanding of the material. Each of these is worth 3 or more points with the possibility of partial credit.
 You will show your work for these questions in addition to stating your answer. These questions will be graded on whether: All Work is Shown, the Answer is Correct, and Correct Mathematical Notation is used. These are essentially the questions that require more work to arrive at the answer.

title: Welcome
content:
Overview Welcome to the online section of MTH 121 Survey of Calculus and Its Applications 1. We begin by giving a brief overview of the course structure and will then expand on these descriptions later in this handbook. Make sure you carefully read through both the entire course handbook and syllabus and if you still have any questions, contact your instructor immediately.
Essentially, the course consists of five main components: lectures, recitations, office hours, homework assignments, and exams.
Lectures Lectures are pre-recorded videos that can be watched at any time. Each video has an accompanying note sheet to be filled in as you watch each lecture. These note sheets are for your benefit and may be checked for completion. To stay on pace with the course material, you are strongly encouraged to complete each lecture on (or before) the scheduled due date.
 See the Attendance Policy for further information. See the Guided Lectures section to start working!  Office Hours Office hours are conducted through both an online discussion board and in-person meetings.
The online discussion board is an opportunity to engage with the instructor, teaching assistant, and other students by asking and answering questions in a text-based format.
The in-person office hours are small-group meetings with the instructor (or teaching assistant), held on a recurring basis at scheduled times.
Recitations Recitations are conducted as an online video conference, and are an opportunity to engage directly with the teaching assistant by asking questions, working through homework problems together, and reviewing lecture material - all in real time!
Homework Assignments The best way to learn mathematics is by practicing it for yourself. Homework will consist of both graded and ungraded problems. The graded homework sets for each lecture will be completed online using WeBWork.
Exams There will be three midterm exams and one cumulative final exam. These exams are paper-based and must be taken in-person at an instructor approved testing center. Please note the exams are not administered online but rather in a paper-based format.

title: Course Information
content:
Prerequisites  MTH 115, ULC 148, or NYS Regents Course B required for registration. ALEKS - Only students who have passed ALEKS with a score of 61 or better are eligible to complete this course (this restriction only applies to the Fall and Spring Semesters).  Delivery Mode This is an online course with in-person exams.
Required Hardware  Textbook - L. Goldstein, D. Schneider, D. Lay, and N. Asmar, Calculus and Its Applications.  The 5th custom UB edition is the official version. The 4th custom UB edition is also sufficient. The standard 13th and 14th editions are also sufficient.   Computer with an up-to-date internet browser. Internet Connectivity: consistent access to high speed internet for the duration of the course. Calculator: Texas Instruments TI-30XIIS(this is the only calculator allowed on the exams)  Required Software  This Course Website – This is the main portal for our class. It contains the syllabus and all information regarding lectures and assignments. UBlearns – Our course UBlearns page will be used as a place to post announcements, grades, and any other sensitive information while the course is in progress. Piazza – The online discussion board for our class. (free) Zoom – Video conferencing software for the online recitations. (free) Webex – Video conferencing software for the online recitations that we may trial later on in the year. (free) WeBWork – The online homework system for our class. It is a free system sponsored by the Mathematical Association of America (MAA) with a server right on campus in the UB Math Department. (free)  Recommended Software  Geogebra Very nice graphing software. (free) WolframAlpha Website that provides nice computational and graphical services in a search engine format. (free) Maple, Mathematica, or Matlab These are heavy duty computational programs (more than we really need) but some of them are free to download as a UB student.  Course Description For students in social, biological, and management sciences. Limits, continuity, differentiation of algebraic and exponential functions; applications; introduces integration. This course is a controlled enrollment (impacted) course. Students who have previously attempted the course and received a grade other than W may repeat the course in the summer or winter; or only in the fall or spring semester with a petition to the College of Arts and Sciences Deans’ Office. To help students achieve greater success, all new UB students are required to complete the ALEKS math assessment tool. New and continuing UB students seeking to enroll in MTH 121 must complete the ALEKS assessment tool within the last 12 months and achieve a required score of 61 as a prerequisite. (ALEKS is not required in Summer/Winter).

title: Exam 1 Study Guide
description: A more detailed look at potential Exam 1 test questions.
content:
Logistics  Date: Thursday, September 26, 2019  Time: 8:45pm-10:15pm ET - (it is a 1.5 hour exam)
 Location: Your exam location is posted on UBlearns.
 What to Bring: You should bring multiple pens / pencils, your approved calculator, and a photo ID.
 Calculator: You are allowed to use only the Texas Instruments TI-30XIIS calculator on the exam. All other calculators are prohibited. See the Calculator and Reference Policy in the syllabus for more details.
 Photo ID: You must bring a photo ID with you to your test site (either a UB student ID or a state-issued ID like a driver's licencse).
  What Not to Bring: Do not bring any bags, books, notes, formula sheets, or other loose items.
 No Formula Sheets: You are not allowed any outside references (e.g., cheat sheets, formula sheets, note cards, or textbooks). See the Calculator and Reference Policy in the syllabus for more details.   Material  Topics: Exam 1 will explicitly cover material from Ch.0 - Ch.1
 Questions: Exam 1 will consist of approximately 15-20 short-answer questions and 3-5 long-answer questions
  Learning Outcomes Being Tested Below is the list of potential exam questions for each section covered in lecture.
Section 0.1 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 0.1 #13, 15, 17, 21, 23, 25, 27, 53
 Evaluate a function at some given \(x\) value. Evaluate a piecewise function at some given \(x\) value. Determine the domain of a function. Use a graph to evaluate a function at some given \(x\) value. Sketch the graph of a function by plotting points.  Section 0.2 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 0.2 #1, 3, 9, 9, 31, 33, 35
 Sketch the graph of a linear function. Sketch the graph of a quadratic function. Sketch the graph of a piecewise function that has pieces involving linear and/or quadratic functions.  Section 0.3 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 0.3 #7, 9, 31, 33
 Express the sum or difference of two rational functions as a rational function. Express the product or quotient of two rational functions as a rational function. Calculate the composition of two functions.  Section 0.4 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 0.4 #1, 3, 5, 7, 31, 33, 39
 State the definition of the zero of a function. State the Quadratic Formula. Use the Quadratic Formula to solve a quadratic equation. Use the Quadratic Formula to find the zeros of a quadratic function. Use the Quadratic Formula to find the intersection points of two curves. Use the Quadratic Formula to solve an equation involving a rational expression. Factor a polynomial of the form \(x^{2}+bx+c\). Factor a polynomial of the form \(ax^{2}+bx+c\). Factor a polynomial of the form \(ax^{3}+bx^{2}+cx\). Factor a polynomial using one of the 5 special case formulae.  Section 0.5 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 0.5 #33, 35, 39, 41, 43, 45, 89, 91
 Identify the different exponential rules. Simplify an exponential expression using the exponent rules.  Section 1.1 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.1 #1, 3, 7, 11, 15, 27, 29
 State the slope formula. State the point-slope formula for the equation of a line. Determine the slope and \(y\)-intercept of a line given the following:  An equation of the form \(y=mx+b\). An equation of the form \(ax+cy=d\).  Sketch an example of a line with positive slope. Similarly for negative slope. Give an equation that describes a Vertical Line. Similarly for a Horizontal Line. Calculate the slope of a line given the following information:  Its graph or Two points on the line.  Find an equation of the line given the following information:  Slope and a point on the line or Two points on the line  Given a line of the form \(y=mx+b\)  Find the slope of a parallel line. Find the slope of a perpendicular line.   Section 1.2 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.2 #1, 3, 17, 19, 21
 Estimate the slope of the curve at designated point given:  A graph of the function and a sketch of the tangent line or A graph of the function.   Section 1.3 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.3 #3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 17, 19, 25, 33, 35, 71, 73
 Differentiate functions of the form \(f(x)=mx+b\). Differentiate functions of the form \(f(x)=b\). Differentiate functions of the form \(f(x)=x^{n}\) using the Power Rule.  Be able to rewrite root functions \(\sqrt[n]{x}=x^{1/n}\) Be able to rewrite fractions \(1/x^{n}=x^{-n}\)  Use the derivative to find the slope of the curve at a given point. Use the derivative to find the slope of the curve at a given \(x\)-value. Use the derivative to find the equation of the tangent line at a given \(x\)-value.  Section 1.4a Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.4 #1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 13, 15, 17, 19, 21
 Numerical Methods  Find the limit of a function given a table of values. Fill in a table of function values to help find the limit of a function.  Graphical Methods  Find the limit of a function given its graph.  State the limit laws. Find the limit of a function using the limit laws. Find the limit of a polynomial or rational function. Calculate a limit using the Factor and Cancel Method.  Section 1.4b Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.4 #29, 33, 41
 State the definition of the derivative of a function \(f(x)\). Use the limit definition of the derivative to calculate the derivative of:  A polynomial of degree 2 or less (multiply out). A rational function (common denominator). A root function (conjugate method).   Section 1.5 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.5 #1, 3, 5, 9, 11, 13, 15
 Given the graph of a function \(f(x)\):  Determine if the function is continuous at a designated number. Determine if the function is differentiable at a designated number. Determine the \(x\)-values where a function is discontinuous. Determine the \(x\)-values where a function is non-differentiable.  State the definition of continuous at a number \(a\). Determine whether a piecewise function is continuous and/or differentiable at a designated number (not given the graph of the function).  Section 1.6 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.6 #1, 5, 9, 11, 13, 17, 19, 29, 41
 State the Constant Multiple Rule. Differentiate functions of the form \(f(x)=kx^{r}\). State the Sum Rule. Differentiate various functions using the constant multiple, sum, and power rules. Differentiate a general power function using the General Power Rule.  Section 1.7 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.7 #1, 3, 7, 13, 19
 Compute derivatives of functions with variables other than \(x\). Compute the second derivative of a function (without needing the General Power Rule). Compute the second derivative of a function (requiring the General Power Rule). Evaluate the second derivative at a given \(x\)-value.  Section 1.8 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 1.8 #1, 3, 7, 9, 13, 17
 Calculate the average rate of change of a function \(f(x)\) over a given interval \([a,b]\). Compute the instantaneous rate of change of a function \(f(x)\) at a given \(x\)-value. Given a position function \(s(t)\) that represents the position of an object moving in a straight line:  Calculate the average velocity over a given time interval \([a,b]\). Find the velocity function \(v(t)\). Find the acceleration function \(a(t)\). Solve problems involving the position, velocity, and acceleration (determine when the position, velocity, or acceleration is a certain value).

title: How to Succeed
content:
Time Management Time management skills are essential in successfully completing this course. On average, expect to spend approximately 15+ hours per week on work for this class (lectures, assignments, studying, reading, etc.). Please understand that a lot of responsibility will fall onto your shoulders to work through the material at the pace described in this website. Any online course demands a large degree of dedication and autonomous study habits from the individual student. If you do feel like you are falling behind, be proactive and reach out to your Instructor or TA!
Daily Workflow For each assigned lecture complete the following:
 Print the corresponding lecture notes. Actively watch the lecture and complete the note sheet. Read the indicated section of the textbook. Complete the assigned ungraded homework problems from the textbook as needed. Complete the graded homework problems on WeBWork. Participate in the recitation section and discussion board.  Work Effectively Turn off your phone. Turn off social media. Close all unnecessary browser windows on your computer. Do not study in front of the TV. You should be actively watching the lecture videos and studying. Active means:
 Mindfully following along with videos Taking handwritten notes Going back if something does not make sense Pausing to try an example for yourself, etc.  Getting Help You are strongly encouraged to ask questions and get help when needed. Do not fall behind! Remember, if you have a question … ask! Chances are good that someone else will also benefit from your question.
We offer several different platforms for you to ask questions and get help:
 Recitation (Online) Office Hours (Online Discussion Board) Office Hours (In Person) Math Help Center - rooms 107 and 110 in the Mathematics Building; open daily 9am-5pm. The Math Place - room 211 in Baldy Hall; open Monday-Thursday 10am-6pm.

title: Assessments
content:
Overview Your final grade will be determined by your performance on the following assessments: Homework Assignments, the Exam Registration Form, Midterm Exams, and the Cumulative Final Exam.
Homework On average, there will be approximately 2-4 problem sets assigned each week. They will be posted on our course website each Tuesday and due the following Tuesday at 11:59pm ET. Your grade for each individual homework set will be calculated as the percentage of your correct answers. Your final Homework grade, will then be calculated as the equally weighted average of these individual homework set scores.
Exam Registration Form The exam registration form is how you communicate to the instructor where you will be taking each of your exams. It is extremely important that you fill this out correctly and by the deadline. Please see the Exam Registration section of the Course Handbook for further instructions on how to complete this form.
Midterm Exams There are three paper-based midterm exams given on the dates listed in the Course Schedule. Your lowest midterm exam score will be dropped. These exams must be taken in-person either at UB or an instructor approved off-campus testing center. Please note the exams are not administered online but rather in a paper-based format.
Midterm Exam 1 Content: Ch.0 - Ch.1 Date: Thursday, September 26, 2019 Time: 8:45pm-10:15pm ET - (it is a 1.5 hour exam) Location: To Be Determined (room Knox 20 if taken at UB)
Midterm Exam 2 Content: Ch.2 - Ch.3 Date: Thursday, October 24, 2019 Time: 8:45pm-10:15pm ET - (it is a 1.5 hour exam) Location: To Be Determined (room Knox 20 if taken at UB)
Midterm Exam 3 Content: Ch.4 - Ch.6 Date: Thursday, November 21, 2019 Time: 8:45pm-10:15pm ET - (it is a 1.5 hour exam) Location: To Be Determined (room Knox 20 if taken at UB)
Final Exam There is one paper-based, cumulative final exam given during Finals Week on the date listed in the Course Schedule. This exam must be taken in-person either at UB or an instructor approved off-campus testing center. Please note this exam is not administered online but rather in a paper-based format.

title: Exam 2 Study Guide
description: A more detailed look at potential Exam 2 test questions.
content:
Logistics  Date: Thursday, October 24, 2019  Time: 8:45pm-10:15pm ET - (it is a 1.5 hour exam)
 Location: Your exam location is posted on UBlearns.
 What to Bring: You should bring multiple pens / pencils, your approved calculator, and a photo ID.
 Calculator: You are allowed to use only the Texas Instruments TI-30XIIS calculator on the exam. All other calculators are prohibited. See the Calculator and Reference Policy in the syllabus for more details.
 Photo ID: You must bring a photo ID with you to your test site (either a UB student ID or a state-issued ID like a driver's licencse).
  What Not to Bring: Do not bring any bags, books, notes, formula sheets, or other loose items.
 No Formula Sheets: You are not allowed any outside references (e.g., cheat sheets, formula sheets, note cards, or textbooks). See the Calculator and Reference Policy in the syllabus for more details.   Material  Topics: Exam 2 will explicitly cover material from Ch.2 - Ch.3
 Questions: Exam 2 will consist of approximately 15-20 short-answer questions and 3-5 long-answer questions.
  Learning Outcomes Being Tested Below is the list of potential exam questions for each section covered in lecture.
Exam 1 Review While concepts from exam 1 will not be explicitly tested on this exam, we do rely heavily on many of the concepts first introduced there. In particular, it may be a good idea to review:
 Section 0.4 How To Solve Equations - Factoring and Quadratic Formula Section 1.6 Basic Derivative Rules  Section 2.1 Additional Practice 2.1 #1, 3, 17, 25, 27, 29, 33, 35 (textbook)
 Given the graph of a function:  Find the intervals of increase and decrease. Find the relative extreme points. Find the absolute extreme points. Find the intervals of concavity. Find the inflection points.  Sketch the graph of a function, given the:  Intervals of increase and decrease Relative extreme points. Absolute extreme points. Intervals of concavity. Inflection points.   Section 2.2 Additional Practice 2.2 #5, 7, 9, 13, 15, 25, 27 (textbook)
 Given the graph of \(f(x)\):  Find the intervals where \(f'(x)\) is positive or negative. Find the intervals where \(f''(x)\) is positive or negative.  Given the graph of \(f'(x)\):  Find the intervals where \(f(x)\) is increasing or decreasing. Find the intervals where \(f(x)\) is concave up or concave down. Find the \(x\)-values where \(f(x)\) has a relative maximum or minimum Find the \(x\)-values where \(f(x)\) has an inflection point.  Sketch the graph of \(f(x)\), given:  The intervals where \(f'(x)\) is positive and negative The \(x\)-values where \(f'(x)=0\) The intervals where \(f''(x)\) is positive and negative The \(x\)-values where \(f';(x)=0\)   Section 2.3 Additional Practice 2.3 #1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 17, 19, 25, 27, 29, 35, 37 (textbook)
 For all of the following problems, you may be given:  the derivatives, \(f'(x)\) or \(f''(x)\), already calculated for you. only the function \(f(x)\), and need to calculate the derivatives for yourself.    Find the critical numbers of a function. Classify the critical numbers of a function using:  the 1st Derivative Test (relative max, relative min, or neither) the 2nd Derivative Test (relative max, relative min, or inconclusive)  Use \(f'(x)\) to find the following about \(f(x)\):  Intervals of increase / decrease. Local extreme points.  Use \(f''(x)\) to find the following about \(f(x)\):  Intervals of concave up / concave down. Inflection points.  Sketch the graph of a function by determining the:  Intervals of increase / decrease. Local extreme points. Intervals of concave up / concave down. Inflection points.   Section 2.4 Additional Practice 2.4 #1, 3, 7, 9, 25, 27 (textbook)
 Find the \(x\) and \(y\) intercepts of a function, if any exist. Sketch the graph of a function by determining the:  Intervals of increase / decrease. Local extreme points. Intervals of concave up / concave down. Inflection points. \(x\) and \(y\) intercepts  Sketch the graph of a function of the form \(f(x)=mx+b + \frac{1}{x}\) by determining the:  Intervals of increase / decrease. Local extreme points. Intervals of concave up / concave down. Inflection points. Vertical Asymptote at \(x=0\) Oblique (Slant) Asymptote at \(y=mx+b\)   Section 2.5 Additional Practice 2.5 #5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15, 17, 19, 27 (textbook)
 Find the absolute maximum (or minimum) of a function:  that has only one critical number. on an interval of the form \([a,\infty)\) or \([a,b]\).  Given a function that describes the motion of a ball thrown straight up into the air:  Determine how long it takes to reach its maximum height. Determine the maximum height.  Solve an optimization problem where the objective and constraint equations are given for you.  Solve the constraint equation for one of the variables. Substitute this result into the objective equation. Optimize the objective equation (that now only has one variable) Justify your answer by using either the First Derivative or Second Derivative Test to show that there is a maximum / minimum there.  Determine the Objective and Constraint Equations for an optimization word problem. Solve an optimization word problem by constructing the objective and constraint equations for yourself - and then going through the optimization process as described above. It will involve one of the following:  Cost / perimeter and area of a rectangle. Surface Area and Volume of a 3-dimensional box. State the final answer using units, if necessary.   Section 2.6 Additional Practice 2.6 #1, 3, 5, 25 (textbook)
 Find the Objective and Constraint Equations for an Inventory Control problem. Solve an Inventory Control problem using the same Optimization techniques from section 2.5.  Section 3.1 Additional Practice 3.1 #1, 3, 7, 9, 13, 15, 19 23 25 29 31 37 (textbook)
 Differentiate a function using the Product Rule. Differentiate a function using the Quotient Rule.  Section 3.2 Additional Practice 3.2 #11-21(odd), 25, 29, 31, 33, 37, 39, 41, 43, 53, 55 (textbook)
 Use the General Power Rule to differentiate \((g(x))^n\). Use the Chain Rule to differentiate a function of the form \(f(g(x))\).  You may be given separate formulas for \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\).  Use the Chain Rule to calculate \(\frac{dy}{dx}\).  You may be given separate formulas for \(y=f(u)\) and \(u=g(x)\).  Evaluate a derivative at a given \(x\)-value. Use the Chain Rule to solve problems involving the rate of change with respect to time. (See 14 and 15 from the homework)  Section 3.3 Additional Practice 3.3 #1, 3, 11, 13, 19, 21, 23, 25, 29, 31, 33, 39, 42, 43, 45 (textbook)
 Use implicit differentiation to calculate \(\frac{dy}{dx}\) in terms of \(x\) and \(y\).  The differentiation may require use of the Product, Quotient, or General Power Rules.  Use implicit differentiation to find the slope of the curve at a designated point. Determine the Related Rates Equation for a given equation. Solve a Related Rates Equation for either \(\frac{dy}{dt}\) or \(\frac{dx}{dt}\) Evaluate a Related Rates Equation given a specified point and derivative. Use this to solve for the unknown derivative value. Solve a Related Rates Problem (like 14-17 from the homework)  You may need to know the Pythagorean Theoerm.

title: Homework
content:
Overview The best way to learn mathematics is by practicing it for yourself. Homework will consist of both graded and ungraded problems.
Graded Homework  Graded Homework The graded homework sets for each lecture will be completed online using WeBWork. In general, they are due every Lecture Date (Tuesday) at 11:59pm ET. See the course schedule for more information.
 Login Information:  Select course: 2019_8_MTH121_Casper or use the above button. Username is your standard UBIT username. Password is your UB Person Number.  Attempts: You have a finite number of attempts on most problems (usually 10). To help you learn the system, most of the problems in the first 4 homework sets will have an infinite number of attempts. Grading: You will receive full credit for a question as long as you ultimately arrive at the correct answer within the allowable number of attempts.  Ungraded Homework The ungraded homework sets for each lecture will be problems assigned from the textbook. They are meant as additional practice to help you prepare for the graded assessments. It is strongly recommended that you attempt at least some of the ungraded textbook problems before starting the graded homework online. The ungraded problems will not be collected or graded.
Some Relevant Course Policies  Academic Integrity Policy Calculator Policy Email Policy Exception Policy Late Policy

 What to Bring: You should bring multiple pens / pencils, your approved calculator, and a photo ID.
 Calculator: You are allowed to use only the Texas Instruments TI-30XIIS calculator on the exam. All other calculators are prohibited. See the Calculator and Reference Policy in the syllabus for more details.
 Photo ID: You must bring a photo ID with you to your test site (either a UB student ID or a state-issued ID like a driver's licencse).
  What Not to Bring: Do not bring any bags, books, notes, formula sheets, or other loose items.
 No Formula Sheets: You are not allowed any outside references (e.g., cheat sheets, formula sheets, note cards, or textbooks). See the Calculator and Reference Policy in the syllabus for more details.   Material  Topics: Exam 3 will explicitly cover material from Ch.4 - Ch.6. Although you will definitely need to know our various derivative rules, like the Product, Quotient, and Chain Rules.
 Questions: Exam 3 will consist of approximately 15-20 short-answer questions and 3-5 long-answer questions.
  Learning Outcomes Being Tested Below is the list of potential exam questions for each section covered in lecture.
Exams 1 and 2 Review While concepts from exams 1 and 2 will not be explicitly tested on this exam, we do rely heavily on many of the concepts first introduced there. In particular, it may be a good idea to review:
 Section 0.4 How To Solve Equations - Factoring and Quadratic Formula Section 1.6 Basic Derivative Rules Section 3.1 Product and Quotient Rules Section 3.2 The Chain Rule  Section 4.1 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 4.1 #17, 19, 21, 23, 25, 29
 Sketch the graph of an exponential function of the form \(b^{x}\) or \(b^{-x}\). Evaluate an exponential function. Simplify an exponential expression using the exponential laws. Solve an exponential equation.  Section 4.2 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 4.2 #9, 11, 13, 15, 17, 25, 27, 29, 31, 33, 35, 37, 43, 45
 State the slope of \(e^{x}\) at \(x=0\). State the derivative of \(e^{x}\). Differentiate functions involving \(e^{x}\).  May require the product, quotient, or chain rules.  Sketch the graph of \(e^{kx}\) or \(e^{-kx}\).  Section 4.3 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 4.3 #1, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 21, 23, 27, 29, 33
 Differentiate functions of the form \(e^{kx}\). Differentiate functions using the General Exponential Rule.  May require the product, quotient, or other chain rules.  Find the equation of the tangent line to a curve at a given \(x\)-value (using the General Exponential Rule to help calculate the derivative). Find and/or classify the critical numbers of a function (using the General Exponential Rule to help calculate the derivative).  Section 4.4 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 4.4 #7, 9, 11, 15, 19, 21, 23, 27, 29, 33, 37, 45, 47
 Sketch the graph of \(\ln x\). State the properties of the graph of the Natural Logarithm function. Use the cancellation properties to simplify an expression. Use the cancellation properties to solve an exponential equation. Use the cancellation properties to solve a logarithmic equation. Write an exponential function in the form \(b^{x}\) in the form \(e^{(\ln b)x}\)  Section 4.5 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 4.5 #1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15, 19, 25, 29
 State the derivative of \(\ln x\). Differentiate functions involving \(\ln x\).  May require the product, quotient, or chain rules.  Differentiate functions using the General Logarithmic Rule.  May require the product, quotient, or other chain rules.   Section 4.6 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 4.6 #1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 23, 27, 31, 33, 35, 43, 45, 49
 State the properties of the Natural Logarithm function. Write an expression as a single logarithm in the form \(\ln(A)\). Differentiate a natural logarithm function by first simplifying it using the log properties. Differentiate a function using the technique of logarithmic differentiation.  Section 5.1 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 5.1 #19, 21, 23, 25, 27, 29, 31, 33, 35, 37, 41, 43, 47, 51
 State the Exponential Growth Equation. State the Exponential Decay Equation.
 Population Growth
 Find the growth constant. Determine the formula that gives the population at time \(t\). Find the size of the population at a given time. Find the rate of growth, \(P'(t)\), of the population at a given time. Determine how long it will take for a growing population to reach a given size.  Radioactive Decay
 Find the decay constant given the half-life. Determine the formula that gives the radioactive mass remaining at time \(t\). Find the remaining mass after a given number of years. Find the rate of decay, \(m'(t)\), of the mass at a given time. Determine how long it will take for a decaying sample to reach a given mass.   Sections 5.2 and 0.5 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 0.5 #97, 99, 101, 103, 105, 107 --- 5.2 #3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 19, 21
 State the formula for compound interest when interest is compounded \(m\) times per year. Calculate the future value of an investment for different compounding periods. Calculate the amount of time needed for a deposit to grow to a specified future value for different compounding periods. State the formula for compound interest when interest is compounded continuously. Calculate the future value of an investment with continuous compounding. Calculate the time needed for a deposit to grow to a specified future value with continuous compounding. Calculate the doubling or tripling time for an investment compounded continuously.  Section 6.1 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 6.1 #1-23(odd)
 Calculate the antiderivative of a function using one of the Basic Indefinite Integral Rules. (You may need to rewrite any root functions or fractions.)  \(f(x)=k\) \(f(x)=x^{n}\qquad n\neq-1\) \(f(x)=x^{-1}\) \(f(x)=e^{x}\) \(f(x)=e^{kx}\)  Identify the Indefinite Integral Properties. Calculate the antiderivative of a function requiring the Sum and Constant Multiple Rules. Calculate the Indefinite Integral of a function that first needs to be simplified by multiplication or division. Find the position function \(s(t)\) (including the \(+C\)) given the velocity function and the starting position. Find the value of \(k\) that makes an integral formula true.  Section 6.2 Additional Practice Textbook problems: 6.2 #1-21(odd)
 Calculate the Definite Integral of a function involving only the Basic Integration Rules. Calculate the Definite Integral of a function requiring the Sum and Constant Multiple Rules. Calculate the Definite Integral of a function that first needs to be simplified by multiplication or division. Identify the Definite Integral Properties that involve the limits of integration. Calculate the Definite Integral of a function using the Definite Integral Properties (that involve the limits of integration). Calculate the Definite Integral of a piecewise-function. Calculate the Displacement of an object moving in a straight line.

title: Recitation
content:
Overview Recitations are conducted as an online video conference, and are an opportunity to engage directly with the teaching assistant by asking questions, working through homework problems together, and reviewing lecture material - all in real time.
Recitations will be held at scheduled times, but will also be recorded and posted in the Recitation Archive for later viewing. We will be using the video conferencing software Zoom which requires a very quick download the first time you attend (and is free for you to use). We may also try out the software Webex for our recitations later on in the semester (also free).
Recitation is scheduled each lecture date at 1-1:50pm
 How To Attend Simply click the above “Join Recitation (Live)” button at the scheduled time. Once the recitation starts it will be held in a Question & Answer format … so come with questions!
 You can ask either verbally through your microphone or using the text-based chat feature. If you ask a question, be prepared to respond back to the instructor's questions. We usually try to ask questions of you to see where you are getting stuck and to see if you know where to go next.  It is strongly recommended that you attempt the assigned homework problems before that day's recitation.
Recitation Archive Click on the above “Recitation Archive” button to view the catalog of all recorded recitations for this session. Recorded recitations will be posted by the following day and depend on the attendance and participation at the live event.

title: Office Hours (online)
content:
Overview The Online Office Hours are conducted through a discussion board. The discussion board is an opportunity to engage with the instructor, teaching assistant, and other students by asking and answering questions in a text based format. We will be using the website Piazza for our course Discussion Board. It will require a very quick initial registration and is free to use.
We encourage you to post your questions during normal business hours (9-5pm ET) as these are the times we will be most active. It is our goal to have all questions answered within 24 hours during the work week (but most likely much sooner).
 Join the Discussion Board  How To Participate To join our discussion board simply click the above button. Once you have registered there are many ways to participate. You can ask questions, you can answer questions, you can just read through other discussions. It is up to you!
We do encourage you to also answer other people's questions; explaining a concept to someone is actually a really good way to learn and retain the information for yourself! (Although do not just simply give the answer!)
Some Relevant Course Policies  Attendance Policy Office Hour Policy  How to Format Your Question Any question posted on the discussion board must adhere to the following conditions or it may be deleted.
  Question Summary: This is essentially the subject line of your question.
 For homework related questions use the format: 2.5 Problem 4 corresponding to question number 4 from section 2.5. For other questions give a brief one-line description.    Question Details: This is essentially the body of your question. Ultimately, we need to see evidence that you have actually attempted the problem.The goal of this discussion board is to help you determine where you are getting stuck, not just give you the answer.
 Restate the entire problem from the homework. Provide at least a portion of your attempted solution. (You can also post photos). Explain where you think you are getting stuck and what the potential issue might be.    Repeated Questions: Ideally, there should only be one post per homework problem. Any subsequent questions should be posted as a follow-up discussion within the original post. This means before posting a question you should look at all old posts to see if it has already been asked.
    "A picture of the Piazza Question Interface. When posting a question students fill out Post Type (question or note), Folder (a tag for the question to help keep things organized), Summary (the subject line of the question), and Details (the main body of the question)."   An Adequate Post Below is an example of what we would consider a good question. This is only meant to give you an idea of what we are looking for when you post a question; your post does not have to look exactly like this.
  "A picture of a student's Piazza Question showing all formatting criteria adequately addressed."   Okay, so why is this such a good post?
 The question summary follows the correct format: 16.7 Problem 1. The student includes their actual homework problem (usually there is some randomization here, so everyone's problems are slightly different). The student includes a photo of their attempted solution (we cut off some of the photo here for brevity). In their actual question, the student has given some explanation as to what they believe is correct in their work and what might be the issue.  An Inadequate Post Below is an example of what we would consider an inadequate question. These are the types of questions that usually elicit our stock response of: Can you post your work? Remember your instructor cannot usually read minds … we need to see what you are doing!
  "A picture of a student's Piazza Question missing most of the correct formatting criteria."   What did the student get correct here?
 The question summary follows the correct format: 3.4 #8. The student includes their actual homework problem.  Alright, so what is missing?
 The student does not include their attempted solution, typed out or as a photo. (Remember we can't read minds!). The student does not give an explanation as to what they believe is correct in their work and what might be the issue. Actually, the student does not even ask a question here! Remember: The goal of this discussion board is to help you determine where you are getting stuck not just give you the answer.

title: Course Policies
content:
Academic Integrity Students must be familiar with and abide by the university’s policies and procedures on Academic Integrity. Any violation of this policy will be pursued to the fullest extent of university policy.
Attendance Policy   Technological Attendance: We will be using UBlearns and UBmail (email) for all official course communications. It is required that you check both of these platforms daily.
  Lecture Attendance: You are expected to watch all assigned lecture videos in their entirety by the assigned lecture date. Attendance records will be kept and used when evaluating make-up exam requests.
 Satisfactory Lecture Attendance: is defined to be a completion rate of 90% or higher for each week's lecture videos by the assigned due date. The completion rate is the amount of time spent watching the video relative to the total length of the video.    Recitation and Office Hour Attendance: Attendance in the recitations and office hours (discussion board) is initially optional although highly recommended.
  Attendance Policy Rider The instructor reserves the right to make lecture and/or recitation and/or office hour attendance a mandatory requirement for any student whose average in the course drops to a C+ or below at any point during the semester. You will receive an email notification from the instructor if this happens to you. If you do receive such a notification you will be required to maintain one or both of the following:
 satisfactory lecture attendance (defined above) weekly attendance at a scheduled recitation or office hour  These additional requirements must then be met in order for you to take any applicable exams. In the event that you do not meet the attendance requirement as stated in the email notification, you will automatically receive a grade of 0 for that exam. The email notification will explicitly list all additional requirements and applicable exams.
Calculator and Reference Policy   The Texas Instruments TI-30XIISis the only authorized calculator allowed on the midterm and final exams. If you are caught with any other type of calculator during an exam, you will receive a grade of 0 for that exam and an academic integrity case will be initiated.
  Outside references of any kind (e.g., cheat sheets, note cards, textbook) are not allowed on the midterm and final exams. If you are caught with any type of outside reference during an exam, you will receive a grade of 0 for that exam and an academic integrity case will be initiated.
  Copyright Policy All course material is protected under applicable copyright law and the academic integrity policy of the university.
 Unauthorized Distribution: Reproduction and distribution of material is prohibited without the instructor's consent. Copies may be made for private, individual study, but should not be shared with unauthorized users. Unauthorized Possession: Posession of any material from previous courses is prohibited.  Any violation of this policy will be pursued to the fullest extent allowable by law and university policy.
Curve Policy All grades are calculated as described in the grading section of this syllabus. There is no curve in this course. Homework assignments and exams are designed to assess your individual understanding of the learning outcomes. Your grade is completely within your control and based solely on your performance.
Email Policy It is required that your university (buffalo.edu) email address be used for all official course email correspondence.
While we encourage everyone to ask questions, email should only be used for personal matters. Any questions related to the course that are not of a personal nature should be asked on the discussion board or during recitation or in-person office hours. Please allow 72 hours during the work week for a response from the instructor. Emails will not be answered over the weekend.
Exam Date and Time Policy  Date: All exams must be taken on the scheduled exam day. Time: All exams must be started at the scheduled time. If you have another class during the scheduled exam time, you must notify the instructor of this conflict through the Exam Registration Form.  Exam Location Policy It is the student's responsibility to find a testing facility, schedule an appointment with this facility, and obtain instructor approval of their arrangements. The testing facility does not need to be the same for every exam.
Every student has two options for where to take each exam :
  On-campus at UB - This is included with your tuition.
 If you are taking an exam at UB, the testing arrangements have already been made for you. However, you still need to fill out the exam registration form.    An approved testing facility outside of UB - The testing site might charge an extra fee.
 The testing facility must be located in the US or Canada. The testing facility should be in a university or college although alternative locations will be considered on a case-by-case basis. In almost all cases, public libraries and high schools are not acceptable test sites and will not be approved. The testing facility should have a dedicated, unbiased proctor that will be present for the duration of the exam.    Exam Make-up Policy Make-up exams will only be given in the event of an emergency situation, religious holiday, or conflict with another regularly scheduled class. Please note that “having a cold” or “not feeling well” does not constitute an emergency situation. In addition to a compelling and serious reason, all make-up exam requests must meet the following requirements:
 Written Documentation: All requests for a make-up exam must provide written documentation of the situation. If you cannot provide written documentation, you will not be allowed to make-up the exam. Student Health Services (Michael Hall): Does not formally excuse students from class and does not provide supporting written documentation. Any request for a make-up exam with only Student Health Services as a reference will be denied. Satisfactory Progress: Any student requesting a make-up exam should be making satisfactory progress in the course at the time of their request. This means they should have satisfactory lecture attendance and at least a 70% Guided Lecture average on the applicable assignments. Any student below either of these thresholds will have their request denied. Timeliness: All exams must be made up by the end of the 1st business day following the date of the original exam. This deadline may be extended at the instructor's discretion for truly extenuating circumstances.  Exam Registration Policy Everyone, regardless of where they are taking the exam, needs to complete the exam registration form.
 Failure to complete the exam registration form by the required deadline and subsequently obtain instructor approval of your exam arrangements will result in an “F” in the course.  Exam Regrade Policy Any request for an exam regrade must be made within 10 business days of the original exam date.
 This is a complete regrade of the exam, with the possibility that questions originally marked correct might be changed to incorrect (so it is possible that your exam score might go up, stay the same, or be lowered in the process).  Exception Policy Requests for exceptions to any policy or grading assessment described in this syllabus will not be granted. This is to ensure that all students are given equal opportunity to succeed in this class and are all graded by the same set of standards.
Fees Your chosen testing site might charge you an extra fee for their proctoring services. This fee is the student's responsibility. If you take the exams at UB there is no fee beyond the normal fees charged with your tuition.
Late Policy All assignments are due by the posted due date and time. Late submissions will not be accepted; deadlines will not be extended for any reason.
 Do not save homework assignments until the last minute. There might be a slight difference in the server clock time with your local clock time.  Once a problem set closes, it will not be reopened for any reason.
Office Hour Policy Participation with the discussion board and office hours in general is initially optional and will not be graded; although it is highly recommended. If your average in the course drops to a B- or below at any point during the semester this policy may be changed at the instructor's discretion. Please see the Attendance Policy and Attendance Policy Rider for further details.
You can post questions on the discussion board at any time. However, please be advised that questions will usually be answered during normal business hours (9-5pm). It is our goal to have all questions answered within 24 hours during the work week (but most likely much sooner).
  If you choose to participate in the discussion board it is expected that:
 You are up-to-date on all lecture material and readings. Your discussion board post follows all correct formatting guidelines.    If you choose to participate in the in-person office hours it is required that:
 You have both watched and taken notes on the lecture material up through that day. You come prepared with your notes and some attempted homework solutions, all nicely organized. The instructor reserves the right to check your lecture notes for completion at any time during office hours. You may be asked to leave if your notes are found to be incomplete.    Recitation Policy Attendance is initially optional and will not be graded; although it is highly recommended. If your average in the course drops to a B- or below at any point during the semester this policy may be changed at the instructor's discretion. Please see the Attendance Policy and Attendance Policy Rider for further details. If you choose to participate in a recitation it is required that:
 You have both watched and taken notes on the lecture material up through that day. You come prepared with your notes and attempted homework solutions readily available.  Please be aware that:
 The instructor reserves the right to check your lecture notes for completion at any time during the recitation. You may be asked to leave if your notes are found to be missing or incomplete. Each online recitation will be recorded and posted in the Recitation Archive.

The deadline for submitting the Exam Registration Form is:  Friday, September 6, 2019 at 11:59pm ET.
 Exam Registration Policy: You will automatically receive a grade of "F" in the course if your exam arrangements are not approved by the instructor by Friday, September 13, 2019 at 5:00pm ET.
 Exam Registration Form  Exam Registration Form Access the Exam Registration Form using the above button. Please refer to the following instructions before completing this form. It is extremely important that you complete this form correctly and timely.
Instructions for Exams Taken at UB For those people planning on taking their exams at UB, the arrangements have already been done for you. Please note that this option is available to everyone and is included with your tuition.
 Step 1: Read through all of the Exam-Related Policies. Step 2: Verify that you do not have a class that conflicts with our scheduled times for Midterm Exams 1-3. Step 3: Verify that you do not have another final exam that conflicts with our scheduled Final Exam time. Note that our Final Exam is scheduled during finals week, so your actual class times will have ended by that point. You can view your final exam schedule on your HUB Student Center. Step 4: Complete the exam registration form indicating that you will be taking the exams at UB; if you do have a conflict, you will be able to indicate this on the form as well. Step 5: If you do have a conflict, you also need to email your instructor a screenshot of both your class schedule and final exam schedule from your HUB Student Center. The screenshot should include both your full name and the applicable schedule. Step 6: That's it!  Instructions for Exams Taken Off-Campus For those people looking to take their exams at an off-campus testing center, these arrangements have not been done for you. It is the student's responsibility to locate a testing center and schedule an appointment with them for our scheduled test date and time. If necessary, you can use different sites for each exam. Your testing center and appointments will then be reviewed by the instructor during the Exam Registration Form Approval Process.
Please note that this option is available to everyone although the off-campus testing site might charge you an additional fee. Any fees charged by an off-campus test site are the student's responsibility.
 Step 1: Read through all of the Exam-Related Policies. Step 2: Contact the testing center at a local college or university. (Use the phone if necessary). Step 3: Find out if they will be open on our scheduled test dates and how much money it will cost you for them to proctor your exam. Step 4: Schedule an appointment with this testing center to take each exam on the scheduled date and time. Remember, it is your responsibility to schedule your appointments. Step 5: Find out the relevant contact information for your test site (Testing Center Name, Phone Number, Website, Email, etc.). Step 6: Email your instructor this relevant contact information. Step 7: Complete the exam registration form indicating that you will not be taking the exam at UB. Step 8: That's it! You will be notified by the instructor if your arrangements are approved or rejected during the Exam Registration Form Approval Process.  The Approval Process Beginning Monday, September 9, 2019 the instructor will review all exam registration form submissions and notify you about the status of your arrangements. You will have at least one day to make adjustments if your arrangements are initially rejected. Approval will be subject to 3 conditions:
 Your registration form is complete with all necessary details and you have emailed your instructor all supporting documentation in the event you have a conflict or are using an off-campus testing center. Your chosen off-campus test site is an acceptable testing location (if applicable). See the Exam Date, Time and Location Policies. The instructor has verified all of your exam appointments with your chosen off-campus test sites (if applicable).  Timeline   Monday, September 9, 2019  - The instructor will begin reviewing all exam registration form submissions.  Thursday, September 12, 2019 at 11:59pm ET - The instructor will notify you whether your form has been approved or rejected. You will have one day to make adjustments if your arrangements are initially rejected.  Friday, September 13, 2019 at 5:00pm ET - This is the final deadline for all people whose arrangements are initially rejected.  How You Will Be Notified You can check the status of your exam registration form in the “Your Grades” section of our UBlearns course site. If the status of your form is:
 approved, you will see your exam locations explicitly listed on UBlearns. rejected, you will see your exam locations listed on UBlearns as “pending”. You will also receive an email notification in this case. not processed yet, the entries for your exam locations will be blank.  Email notifications will only be sent out if there is a problem with your form. You will not receive an email notification if it has been approved.
Exam Registration Form Grading The Exam Registration Form is worth a total of  2% points.
You will receive  1% point  for completing the registration form by the Exam Registration Form deadline, Friday, September 6, 2019 at 11:59pm ET.
 Any missing information on your form or supporting documentation will result in 0 points for this portion of the assignment. Any changes to your exam arrangements after they have been approved by an instructor will result in 0 points for this portion of the assignment.  You will receive the remaining 1% point  if all of your exam arrangements are approved by the instructor by Friday, September 13, 2019 at 5:00pm ET.
 For off-campus testing, any unscheduled appointments will result in 0 points for this portion of the assignment. For exam conflicts, any missing documentation will result in 0 points for this portion of the assignment. Any changes to your exam arrangements after this deadline will result in 0 points for this portion of the assignment.

title: Further Information
content:
Accessibility Resources If you have any disability which requires reasonable accommodations to enable you to participate in this course, please contact the Office of Accessibility Resources in 60 Capen Hall, 716-645-2608 and also the instructor of this course during the first week of class. The office will provide you with information and review appropriate arrangements for reasonable accommodations.
Changes to the Syllabus This syllabus is subject to amendments as needed. Changes will be announced to the class electronically via email and posted on the course UBlearns page.
Controlled Enrollment Courses This is a Controlled Enrollment Course. If you need to repeat this course in the future (because you failed it, resigned from it, etc. at the first attempt) you may be forced to do it in a UB summer or winter session. Registering to repeat this course in a Fall or Spring semester may be difficult or impossible. For more information see the Repeat Policy in the UB Undergraduate Catalog.
Critical Campus Resources Sexual Violence UB is committed to providing a safe learning environment free of all forms of discrimination and sexual harassment, including sexual assault, domestic and dating violence and stalking. If you have experienced gender-based violence (intimate partner violence, attempted or completed sexual assault, harassment, coercion, stalking, etc.), UB has resources to help. This includes academic accommodations, health and counseling services, housing accommodations, helping with legal protective orders, and assistance with reporting the incident to police or other UB officials if you so choose. Please contact UB’s Title IX Coordinator at 716-645-2266 for more information. For confidential assistance, you may also contact a Crisis Services Campus Advocate at 716-796-4399.
Mental Health As a student you may experience a range of issues that can cause barriers to learning or reduce your ability to participate in daily activities. These might include strained relationships, anxiety, high levels of stress, alcohol/drug problems, feeling down, health concerns, or unwanted sexual experiences. Counseling, Health Services, and Health Promotion are here to help with these or other issues you may experience. You can learn more about these programs and services by contacting:
 Counseling Services 120 Richmond Quad (North Campus), 716-645-2720 202 Michael Hall (South Campus), 716-829-5800 Health Services Michael Hall (South Campus), 716-829-3316 Health Promotion 114 Student Union (North Campus), 716-645-2837  Portfolio If you are completing this course as part of your UB Curriculum requirements, please select an ‘artifact’ from this course that is representative of your learning and upload it to your UBPortfolio account. Templates have been created for this purpose. Artifacts include homework assignments, exams, research papers, projects, lab reports, presentations, and other course materials. Your final UB Curriculum requirement, UBC 399: UB Curriculum Capstone, will require you to submit these ‘artifacts’ as you process and reflect on your achievement and growth through the UB Curriculum. For more information, see the UB Curriculum Capstone website.

title: Getting Help
content:
Content Questions All content related questions about the material or the course should be asked either through the discussion board or during recitation. Most questions that we receive fall under this category - so most likely this is where you should turn.
  Online Office Hours - Conducted through our course discussion board. Enroll by following the instructions described in the syllabus.
  In-Person Office Hours - Weekly, recurring, small-group meetings with the instructor.
  Recitation - We have both live, online recitations held at scheduled times, and also the recitation archive, a listing of all previously recorded recitations. Join a meeting by following the instructions described in the syllabus.
  Syllabus and Handbook - There is a lot of course information already included in the Course Handbook and Syllabus. If you have a general question about the course, make sure you look here first!
  Examples of Content Related Questions:
 In example 3 from the lecture, what happened to the “4x” after step 5? (Post on the discussion board or ask during recitation.) I am having difficulty on question #2 from the homework … (Post on the discussion board or ask during recitation.) How do I calculate my grade? (Look in the syllabus!) When are the exams? (Look in the syllabus!)  Personal Questions All personal questions should be asked by emailing your instructor.
 Email Policy - Make sure you read over the Email Policy before emailing your instructor. Remember that only personal questions should be asked by email. Any general questions about the course content should be asked through the discussion board, in-person office hours, or recitation.  Examples of Personal Situations where email is preferred:
 Any discussion of your personal grades. Any discussion of accommodations through the Accessibility Office. Any discussion of your medical conditions. Any discussion of a personal situation affecting your progress in the course.  Examples of Questions that should not be asked by email:
 In example 3 from the lecture, what happened to the “4x” after step 5? (Post on the discussion board or ask during recitation.) I am having difficulty on question #2 from the homework … (Post on the discussion board or ask during recitation.) How do I calculate my grade? (Look in the syllabus!) When are the exams? (Look in the syllabus!)

title: Learning Outcomes
content:
Unit 1 The following learning outcomes will be assessed in the Homework, Midterm Exam #1, and Final Exam:
 Recognize linear, polynomial, rational, and power functions, understand their basic properties and know how to evaluate them. Compute zeros of quadratic functions. Compute limits of algebraic functions graphically, numerically, and algebraically. Interpret the derivative graphically as the slope of the tangent to the graph of a function and algebraically as the limit of difference quotients. Compute derivatives of basic algebraic functions.  Unit 2 The following learning outcomes will be assessed in the Homework, Midterm Exam #2, and Final Exam:
 Use limits and derivatives to construct, analyze, and interpret the graph of a function. Use derivatives to analyze and solve applied optimization problems. Compute the first and higher order derivatives using derivative rules, including the chain rule and implicit differentiation.  Unit 3 The following learning outcomes will be assessed in the Homework, Midterm Exams #2-3, and Final Exam:
 Simplify algebraic expressions involving exponents and logarithms. Compute derivatives of exponential and logarithm functions.  Unit 4 The following learning outcomes will be assessed in the Homework, Midterm Exam #3, and Final Exam:
 Use exponential functions and logarithms in problems involving compound interest rates, and exponential growth and decay. Compute indefinite and definite integrals of basic functions using anti-derivative rules and the fundamental theorem of calculus. represent area as a definite integral and interpret the result in applications.  Meta The following learning outcomes will be assessed in all Homework, Midterm Exams #1-3, and the Final Exam:
 Choose appropriate methods or models for a given problem, using information from observed or deduced data and knowledge of the system being studied. Employ quantitative methods, mathematical models, statistics, and/or logic to solve real-world problems beyond the level of basic algebra. Identify common mistakes and/or limitations in empirical and deductive reasoning, and in mathematical, quantitative, and/or logical problem solving. Interpret mathematical models, formulas, graphs, and/or tables, to draw inferences from them, and explain these inferences.

title: Troubleshooting
content:
If you are having difficulty viewing the lecture videos, try the following:
 Check your internet connection. Videos might take longer to load on a slow connection. Give the video extra time to load once you select play. Make sure you are using the latest version of your internet browser: Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Opera, Safari, etc… Some older versions of Chrome have been known to cause issues. Close all open programs, browser windows, browser tabs besides the one window needed for the video. Completely close and restart your browser. Clear your browser history and cookies. Try a different browser.
